Bringing a fresh approach to building applications for the logistics industry.

MOVEL (name changed) is a Mumbai based ERP software solutions company. One of its wings focusses on building solutions for different stakeholders in the shipping logistics industry. Due to some new client requirements, MOVEL reached out to us with the desire to bring in a fresh ‘design first’ approach to building their software solutions.

Like many other ERP solutions companies, especially in India, the workforce here, is primarily ‘engineering’ focussed. Due to that, as sound as the solutions are technologically, their usability, experience, extensibility etc, tended to be neglected. Our engagement started with a very specific focus— to build a customer portal for a certain logistics player (hereafter referred to as 'MOVEL's client')— but soon spread wide, making a much larger eco-system of opportunities visible.

Duration
4 months (Aug ’18 - Nov ’18)
Client
MOVEL (name changed)
Role
Strategy . Product Management . UX
Core Team
Abrar . Sheneille
Outcomes
Product Design & Development . Service Strategy & Development Roadmap

Defining the Scope

The scale & complexity of MOVEL’s ERP solutions are considerable, and we came with no prior knowledge about the workings of the logistics sector in India. With this in mind, MOVEL decided to kick off the engagement with the following brief— to strategise & design a ‘customer portal’ as an extension to their existing ERP solution.

This sort of specificity presented us a perfect opportunity to start understanding a whole new sector, and to define a realistic roadmap towards substantial outcomes.

Process

How does a shipment move from point A to B?
The endless touch-points & actors that exist along the journey of a shipment, not to mention the social & political environment surrounding it, make the process anything but simple to comprehend.

To uncover these complexities we went through several conversations with company directors, product owners, sales staff, client service staff etc. That, along with a healthy consumption of sticky notes & (our very own) emoji story blocks, slowly started making the workings of the logistics business, clearer to us. This process continued until the very end.

But…Why Customer Portal? And Who is the ‘Customer?’
Inefficient customer engagement processes, is what triggered MOVEL with the idea of the portal. But before unpacking that, we needed to understand this ‘customer’. This proved to be a big challenge, since, us being external consultants, engaging with MOVEL's client would be viewed as suspicious.

We had to work around this by trying to see the ‘customers’ through the eyes of those who have interacted with them in plenty. For this, we conducted user stories & prioritisation workshops with the MOVEL team. This also helped us define certain core principles and characteristics that formed the basis of the customer portal. For example, ‘I want to know where my shipments are at any point in time’— this emerged as the priority customer need that the portal needed to address.

‘I want to know where my shipments are at any point in time'— this emerged as the priority customer need, that the portal needed to address.

Moving From Ideas To Action: Design and Development
From quick scribbles on paper, to detailed UX flows & mockups using tools like Sketch and In-vision, we were building all kinds of prototypes, right from the get go. This way we could constantly share, test, discuss, iterate and stay aligned as a team. Also, this approach really got the momentum going with regards to execution.

We used scrum methodologies to make the designer - developer collaboration more efficient. As part of this, we built a ‘UI Component Library’— the lego blocks, so to speak— with a vision to eventually apply standardised UX-UI guidelines across all MOVEL products.

Constant prototyping from the get go, helped us test, discuss, iterate & stay aligned as a team at all times.

Moving beyond the Portal to a Business Analytics Tool
Soon after the major heavy lifting was done on the customer portal front, MOVEL was keep to explore with us, another idea, that they had been toying with— a business analytics tool for MOVEL's client's internal management team. This led us on a journey of deconstructing said client's business from the point of view of sales, operations & finance. We used similar tools & processes to identify key performance metrics for each of these departments, and went through several iterations to translate them into analytics dashboards.

But beyond designing 'UX modules’ for business analytics, what this exercise triggered, were conversations & articulations of the workings & interconnectedness of a much larger eco-system. More on this later.

Beyond designing 'UX Modules' for business analytics, we facilitated the articulation of a much larger eco system.

Reflections on Product Management.
I wasn’t a product manager in the traditional sense, since our roles were quite interdisciplinary. Nonetheless, this was the first time I was actively playing the part. Besides developing strategies, roadmaps, timelines & organising processes, I’d negotiate with other stakeholders in the company— product owners, directors etc— for planning, updates, reviews etc. I acted as a buffer between them & my team, trying to find the right balance between isolation & inclusion.

It was a learning process, and I faltered at times, but some of my key learnings were— allowing roadmaps & strategies to respond to change, clearly & frequently communicating with the team, and most of all, ‘clearing up the road ahead, so that the team can do its job’.

Outcome

1 | Customer Portal
An online service that allows MOVEL's client's customers, to track their shipments, make payments & avail other services, thereby reducing time consuming, in-person interactions.

2 | Business Analytics Tool
An analytics tool that surfaces key performance metrics, thereby helping MOVEL's client's upper management, to make better, data-supported decisions.

Highlights

Facilitating the articulation of tacit knowledge, bringing clarity for all.
The folks from MOVEL's product team have deep, tacit knowledge about the logistics sector in India. To draw it out, we facilitated frequent discussions & workshops, which helped us make better informed decisions while designing the products. The unexpected highlight here, was that this process generated clarity not only for us, but also for the MOVEL team.

Sharing human centered design tools & mental models.
Throughout the project, while working closely with a product owner at MOVEL, we engaged in frequent knowledge sharing sessions. It was great to see that some of our tools & processes were even being adopted by him, one such occasion being, when in a document, he framed user feedback & suggestions in the form of ‘user stories’.

Challenges Faced

Understanding we are designing a framework, not a product.
MOVEL is a solutions company, not a products company. Meaning, their software solutions are customised as per client needs, making each implementation slightly different from the other. This meant that we had to stop thinking of ‘one solution to fit them all’ but instead, devise ‘one framework to adapt to them all.’

To do this, for example, we started thinking of the customer portal as a set of 'modules', rather than a product— shipment tracking module, service request module, invoices & payments module etc. As we designed each of these, we created supporting documentation & guidelines to help future development & implemention teams, to stick to some of the core principles, around which the portal was designed. Also as part of this effort, we developed a ‘UI components library’— the lego bricks so to speak— to bring some UI consistency, across future product implementations.

Since each solution is customised as per client needs, we had to stop thinking of ‘one solution to fit them all’ but instead, devise ‘one framework to adapt to them all.’

Decoding the complexities of the logistics industry.
To address this, we made our discussion & workshop sessions visual, so as to generate clarity and alignment across the team.

No contact with end users.
Since reaching the end user through our client seemed tricky, we personally reached out to a couple of executives from the shipping industry, who agreed to have a sit down with us. Meeting with them gave us at least some insight, into the life, needs & painpoints of our potential end users.

Besides that, as mentioned earlier, we drew insights by workshopping with the experienced members of the MOVEL team, who have been developing solutions for this industry, and its people, for several years.

The Perspective Shift: From Product to Solutions Ecosystem

As our business understanding gradually increased through the course of the project, a much larger ecosystem of opportunities started becoming visible to us. We realised that moving forward, a service design approach would be needed to create disruptive solutions, in a vastly complex industry. We shared these thoughts with some of the stakeholders at MOVEL.

Since they were keep to explore these opportunities, we started putting words to ideas, mapping out this ‘ecosystem' and plotting out the big picture roadmap. The intention was 2 fold— to optimise MOVEL's client's internal processes, and to create a seamless customer experience. After the usual conversations, brainstorms, system maps & service blueprints, the outcome was a presentation, charting out the vision, ecosystem & a roadmap for a way forward.

We started mapping out an ecosystem of solutions— to optimise MOVEL's client's internal processes, and to create a seamless customer experience.

Now What?

While the ambitious plan around creating a solutions eco-system continues to be a point of interest for MOVEL, it hibernates at the moment.

The customer portal came about because of a client requirement, and ever since, many others have shown interest as well. Work on the first implementation of the portal is set to begin in April ’19.

We hope to continue consulting, designing & even implementing solutions with MOVEL in the coming future.
